You're definitely going to do well in analogies so effectively he hadn't been to the vector space that do well in analogies because this means that you've got this direction which is the doer and then you can immediately say that's the doer vector which you can get from subtracting clean from swimmer and that's right so clean from janitor and then we can add it on to swim and we'll get somewhere close to swimmer so his space actually did do that.

And so this isn't so the moral in some senses if you have if you kind of do carefully control accounts and so on that conventional methods can also give you good word vector spaces and I mean so that was actually the starting off point for our work on glove.

So that essentially there've been these two schools of work there've been this school of work that've been explored more in cogside and anywhere else which had been based on counting and transforming counts and you know it had some advantages or it seemed that had some advantages right that you're making sort of efficient use of statistics because you're using the global statistics of the whole matrix directly to estimate things.
And at that point up until then it really only being used to capture words similarity and a lot of it has suffered from disproportionate importance given to large counts.

But Doug Rody has sort of started to show how to solve both of these problems and so on the other hand there'd been these neural network methods which are kind of direct prediction methods that we're defining that probability distribution and trying to predict the words that occur.

And they had some advantages right the fact that you're sampling means that you're not going to run out of memory hopefully I know we've had some memory problems of homework one but in principle you're not as bad a memory position and if you have to construct a huge matrix because you're going linearly.
But you know since you're doing it sample by sample it's inefficient use of statistics.
Okay and so but on the other hand, meklav's work it performed perfectly not perfectly that really well.
So this sort of led into this work that Jeffrey Pannington, which is social and media,
can we sort of combine these ideas and sort of have some of the goodness of the neural net methods while trying to do things with some kind of count matrix.

And so in particular we wanted to get the result in a slightly less hacky way that you want to have components of meaning being linear operations in the vector space that they're just some effect to your actions.
And so the crucial observation of this model was that we could use ratios of co-occurrence probabilities to encode meaning components.
And so the idea here is if you have a word like ice and you say how often the things going to occur with that well solid should occur a lot and gas should end.
But well what is also going to occur a lot and some random word won't occur much if you have.
Oops if you have steam.

You get the opposite pattern with solid and gas right but so the thing to notice is it's not enough to just have large by itself because large appears both here and here or small appears there and there.
The thing that's interesting is sort of the difference between these components and they're indicating a meaning component and so we can get it that.

If we look at the ratio of co-occurrence probabilities and so for the ratio of co-occurrence probabilities this is a dimension of meaning and where for other words this sort of ratio cancels out to about one.
And so in this slide I've moved so it's not my small and large but these are actually actual counts from a quarter so we roughly get the mention of meaning between solid and gas.
Other ones coming out is about one because they're not the dimension of meaning.
And so it seems like what we want is we want to have ratio of co-occurrence probabilities become linear in our space and then we're in a good business.

And so that's what we want to set about doing well how can you do that well the way you can do that is by if you can make the dot products equal to the log of the co-occurrence probability then immediately you get the fact that when you have a vector difference it turns into a ratio of the co-occurrence probabilities.
And so essentially the whole of the model is that we want to have dot products or logs of co-occurrence probabilities.

And so that's what we do. So here is our objective function here and it's made to look a little bit more complicated but essentially we've got the squared loss here and then we want to say the dot product should be as similar as possible to the log of the co-occurrence probability.

And so you'll there'll be loss to the extent that they're not the same but we kind of complexified a little by putting in bias terms for both of the two words because maybe the word is just overall common and likes to occur cur things or uncommon or doesn't.

And then we do one more little trick because every fund does tricks to make the performance better is that we also use this f function in front so that we're sort of capping the effect that very common word pairs can have on the performance of the system.

And so that gave us the glove model of word vectors and theoretically the interest of this was you know a lot of the preceding literature would be there been these count methods and there'd been these prediction methods.

And the hope was that this could sort of unify the two by showing you how you could have a method that is estimated simply off account matrix but is done in the same kind of iterative loss based estimation method that's used for the neural methods to get good word vectors.

And this also worked to give good word vectors so here's glove results for the word frog and frogs and toad are obvious but you know these different kinds of words various kinds of pretty tree frogs and things like that.
Okay, so then go from here and say a little bit more about some of the work on evaluating word vectors and this is maybe also a chance to just talk a little bit about evaluation altogether.
So normally in NLP when we do evaluation the first thing that comes up is intrinsic versus extrinsic evaluation.
So normally if there's something we're trying to do like model word similarity with word vectors or we're trying to put parts of speech on words or something.
We can just have an intrinsic evaluation of saying how good a job did you get are you guessing the right part of speech are you putting synonyms close together.
And that's sort of normally very easy to do and fast to compute and it's useful to do because it helps us understand the system.

On the other hand, a lot of the time those intrinsic evaluations it's not very clear where where they're having done well on that task is really going to help us build the amazing natural language understanding robots that we so are not really desire.

So people are also very interested in extrinsic evaluations and so extrinsically is then saying well suppose you use this new stuff in a real system doesn't make performance go up and it's then sort of definition or what counts to you as a real system.

But normally that's meaning it's some application that human beings actually care about and like to use so that's something like web search or question answering or a phone dialogue system or something like that.

That you can put it into that system and the numbers get go up. So that seems what you want to do you want to have stuff that works in real tasks of course there is sort of on the other hand a lot of things are a lot harder than so it's much more work to do such an evaluation and a run different variants of a system and even when the results are poor or great sometimes it's hard to diagnose.

If your great new word vectors don't work better in the system you know it might be for sort of some extraneous reason about how the system was built it's sort of hiding all your magic and if you just change the rest of the system of some Lee show it's good effect so it's kind of hard to do sort of.

And a portion of goodness and badness. Okay so today I'm mainly going to say a little bit more about these intrinsic word vector evaluations that we've talked about so we've talked quite a bit about these analogies so if we're actually working out the analogies it turns out that normally what people are doing is working out a cosine distance and angle between.

And different word candidates to work out which is the word solves the analogy which is another little tiny wrinkle of difference there and there's also one other trick that people commonly use they forbid the system from returning one of the three words you put into the analogy.

Okay but nevertheless so this is something that you can evaluate here and now some glove visualizations and so these glove visualizations show exactly the same kind of linearity property that Doug rodea discovered which means that analogies work sort of by construction because our vector space wanted to make meaning components linear so this is then showing a gender display.
This is showing one between companies and their CEOs kind of cool and you can also do more syntactic facts so this is showing positive comparative and supportive of adjectives.
Yeah so to mash me call I've came up with this idea of doing these analogy tasks and so he built a data set with a lot of analogies in it.

It's sort of a bit of a weirdo data set because it sort of tests a few random different things which may have been things that his system worked well on but you know it tests countries and capitals countries.
You know cities and states countries and currencies so there are a bunch of semantic things that tests and then there are some.
Here's a big table of results that comes from our glove paper so not surprisingly the glove paper performed best in this evaluation because there's our paper.
But I mean perhaps you know perhaps the things to start to notice is yeah if you just do a plain SVD on counts you know that that works.

A bombably badly for these analogy tasks but you know kind of as Doug Rody showed if you start then doing manipulations of the count matrix before you do an SVD you can actually start to produce an SVD based system that actually performs quite well on these tasks.

You know not badly against other things other things that you will discover right at the top there are 100 dimensional ones and at the bottom there are some thousand dimensional ones and other 300 dimensional ones.
At least when you're training on a bigger amount of text bigger dimensionality definitely works better and I'll come back to that in a minute.

The amount of text makes a difference as well right so we're going up from sort of one to one point five billion words the beginning to these ones down here being trained over 42 billion words of text and perhaps unsurprisingly the 42 billion words of text ones work better.

So it's big data here are a couple more stats from this paper so this is a graph of dimensionality and what the performance is so for the three lines the green ones semantic the blue ones the syntactic analogies and sort of reds the overall score so sort of what you see is up to dimensionality 300 things are clearly increasing quite a bit and then it gets fairly flat which is precisely why you find a lot of word vectors that are of different ways.

So we mentioned how they 300 this one's showing what window size so this is sort of what we talked about symmetric on both sides window size and as it goes from 246-810 and so what you see is if you use a very small window like two that actually works the the
factually this syntactic gets a bit better as well but especially the semantic the gains. The right graph shows that if you only use context on one side your numbers are not good.
Okay so I sort of just wanted to sort of sneak in a little cameo of a couple of recent bits of work sort of a first of what things people are doing with word vectors.

So this one was actually by two standard people now the best this would be the best story if I could say that this was a final project in this class last year but unfortunately that's not true this paper has nothing to do with this class.

But anyway, see in your own you are actually had some sort of clever and very Matthew ideas where they are using matrix perturbation theory and sort of showing how dimensionality and word vectors actually sort of feeds into the bias variance trade off if you've seen that in other parts of machine learning.
And I'm not even going to attempt to explain their paper but here it is that they did really well with this paper they got old talk at Europe from it.
And so but there's sort of an interesting result of what you see with these word vectors which is in the way kind of surprising.
So this is showing doing word vector dimensions from zero up to 10,000 so we're going way higher than we talked about before.
And so what you discover which people are known for ages is that there's sort of a little blip that somewhere around 200, 300 which seems to optimize performance.

So I'm using those sizes but the thing that they were sort of doing a lot of their theory about is kind of surprising is well surely if you have a humongous humongous number like if you're using 10,000 dimensional vectors.

You know you're trying to estimate another two orders of magnitude more numbers for every word surely things should just fall apart because you've got hopelessly many parameters relative to the amount of training data that you're trying to estimate these numbers from.

And so the interesting result that they show is that things don't fall apart and that you can essentially go out to these huge huge dimensionalities and the performance stays flat and that they've got a lot of theory sort of predicting why that's actually going to end up being the case.

Yeah so for training these models iteratively this is or ingest showing glove training you know they keep on getting better for a while so you know just go out go sleep see in the morning how it's doing right so that if you're running it for 24 hours your numbers are better than if you only ran it for six hours.

And that's true for a lot of deep learning models sorry so this is the key reason why you don't want to start your assignment the night before it's due because even if you program it perfectly you might just not have enough time for it to run so that you produce good numbers at the end of it.
Okay yeah so.
So couple more things on that yeah so.

What are we showing here so these again semantics, intact and overall numbers so there's sort of two things are solving mix together here one is if we just look at the overall numbers they're highest over here.

Which is this 42 billion common crawl web pages corpus that gives us the highest overall number but there's sort of something else that's interesting in this graph which is that using Wikipedia works frequently well so that you actually find that 1.6 billion tokens of Wikipedia works better than 4.3 billion tokens of news why it used paper article data and so.
I think that sort of actually makes sense which is well you know the job of encyclopedias is to sort of explain concepts and how they relate to each other right so that.
Encyclopedias are just much more expository.

Texts that show all the connections between things whereas newspapers in general aren't trying to exposit how things fit together they're just telling you about you know who got shot dead last night or something like that right so.
So this is sort of interesting fact that this Wikipedia data kind of really is sort of is differentially useful for.
Making word vectors and you know in fact you know when we did very well without glove word vectors and lots of people use those you know I think actually one of the reasons why they work so well.
Is that the original word to vectors that Google distributes a built only on Google news data where else sort of have this Wikipedia data inside them okay.

Where people have wanted to model humans judgments of similarity so like a good site person what you do is you find your classroom of psycho and undergrads and you show them pairs of words and say rate these things for similarity on a scale of one to 10 and lots of that data has been collected and you work out the mean over human beings and they give numbers like this of tiger and cat 7.35 tiger similar to tiger 10.

Yeah so we had that problem right at the beginning of Clinton and how that could be various people and that's perhaps in some sense the simplest case of words being ambiguous when you have names which have reference to different people.
But it's not only true of name so by and large words and human languages and biguous and have lots of meanings.
That's especially true of common words they always have lots of meaning it's especially true of words that have existed for a long time.

It's not true of new very technical words you know cast an oma I think that only has one meaning but you know if you think of any relatively common word and stats scratching your head for a moment you'll find it has lots of meanings.
I maybe this is even such a common word but my end word I've got here is pike pike has lots of meanings it has meanings like.
It's a kind of fish yeah so there's a fish that's a pike what else is a pike.
A large spear yes so large spears that pike other kinds of pikes.

Gymnastics move or in diving move it's a road yeah so there are lots of meanings there are other meanings I mean Australian English pikes also uses a verb to mean the pull out of doing something like we were all going to go out to a nightclub later but Joe Pike.

I don't think that usage is common in this country but you can try it out but lots of meanings and you know this isn't only true of the word pike right pick any other simple word right you can pick a word like shell or field or house or make you know they have lots of meanings when it comes down to it so you know but so how can this work we just have one meaning for words.
And that's an interesting question and something that we were actually interested in early on so.
Even before the word to VEC paper came out back in 2012 we were playing around with neural word vectors and we thought boy this is so broken having only one sense for a word.
Why don't we come up with a model that has multiple sensors for a word and so we did that and we did it in a pretty crude way I guess.

The way we did it is say well let's for each common word let's cluster all the context in which it occurs and then we'll see if there seem to be multiple clear clusters by some criterion for that word and if so we'll just sort of split the word into pseudo word.

So if it seems like that there are five clusters for the word example I meant to use here is jaguar five clusters for the word jaguar or just call them jaguar one jaguar two jaguar three four five so it's just literally change the word in our corpus according to its cluster number.
And then we run our word vectoring algorithm and so we get a representation for each of those sensors of the word.
And basically that works right so up the top is jaguar one next to luxury and convertible here is I guess there's a very old version of macOS called jaguar and you remember I remember that one.
Right so jaguar is right next to software and Microsoft up there so that's hopeful.
Here's the jaguar that's right next to the hunter and I'm confused on this one this jaguar's near solo musical keyboard and strings there are band of band of keyboard called jaguar.
I'm not quite sure about that one but anyway it's sort of basically works.
But there was sort of crude and it's also perhaps problematic so a lot of time the divisions between sensors aren't very clear.

Right a lot of sensors are actually related to each other and overlapping because when house sensors normally arrive is that people stretch the meanings of words it's not that they just sort of randomly wake up the next morning and say I know carpet I could also refer to that as stone.
And give a new sense to the word stone right you sort of take something that you know about like a web and you extend it metaphorically to other users of webbing.
So here's a perhaps more interesting thing and so this is the other son G. Aurora paper that I was going to mention so that what happens if you don't.

If you don't have more than one sense for each word well effectively what you get is that the word back to that you learn is what's referred to by physicists and fancy people as a super position of the word vectors of the different sentences different sensors.
And so that effectively my meaning of pike is sort of a weighted average of the vectors for the different sensors of pike and the components are just weighted by their frequency.

So that part maybe is perhaps not too surprising but the part that's really surprising is well if we just averaging these word vectors you think you couldn't get anything out of the average right like if I tell you I'm thinking of two numbers and there.
You know weighted sum is 54 what are my two numbers right you're sort of really short of information to be able to answer my question but well you know for these word vectors.
We have these high dimensional spaces and even though there are a lot of words the spaces so vast with all its dimensions that actual words or sensors are very sparse in that space.
And so it turns out that there's this whole literature on sparse coding compress sensing some of which is actually done by people in the stats department here.

Which shows that in these cases where you have these sort of sparse codes in these high dimensional spaces you can actually commonly reconstruct out the components of a super position even though all you've done has sort of done this weighted average.
And so this paper looks at how you can do this and so they have these underlying meaning components and they sort of separated out so.
And so the high has one meaning component that's in the space of trousers, blouse, waistcoat that makes sense and other one in this meaning component of season teams winning league makes sense.
School line goal of equalizer clinching scoreless this one seems to overlap with this one a bit but here tie this is sort of cable ties and wire ties and things like that.
So they're actually able to pull out the different sense meanings from outside out of the meaning of the word.

So that is a kind of a cool thing I just want to say one more thing okay all the evaluation so far was intrinsic you also might want to do extrinsic evaluation why why word factors excited people and LPs so much is it turned out that having this meaning.

And so this is doing named entity recognition which is labeling persons and locations and organizations but you know it's typical of many tasks of what people found was if you started with a model without sort of word representations and you throw in your word vectors regardless of whether they're word to vector glove ones just kind of your numbers go up a couple of the cent or more.

And so the word vectors were just sort of this useful source that you could throw into any NLP system that you built and your numbers went up so that they're just a very effective technology which actually did work and basically any extrinsic task you tried it on okay thanks a lot.

+ Related to general evaluation in NLP: Intrinsic vs extrinsic + Intrinsic Evaluation on a specific/intermediate subtask Fast to compute Helps to understand that system Not clear if really helpful unless correlation to real taskis established + Extrinsic: Evaluation on a real task Can take a long time to compute accuracy Unclear if the subsystem is the problem or its interaction or other subsystems IF replacing exactly one subsystem with another improves accuracy > Winning!
